Text.Value: Come to think of it, you remind me of someone he was writing a piece about.
He wants some fluff piece about the heroic Steel Watch keeping the mob at bay - whether or not that's the truth or not.

EditorData.NodeContext: Hint of derision - badmouthing her boss here

Text.Value: I've been sent down here by my editor at the Baldur's Mouth Gazette to cover the chaos at the gate.
Of course, I can't write any of that. My editor only releases stories his friend Lord Gortash approves of, and he's very selective.
You're one of the lucky ones, then. Everyone else I've spoken to has been flat out refused - men, women, children, young and old. It's been chaos.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Lens makes a quick note on her paper as she speaks

Text.Value: Criticising the Steel Watch? That's not an opinion you hear often.
Ah! Are you trying to get into the city?

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Lens has a pen and paper in hand, as if she's stood making notes/obsevations, and has stopped to talk to the player.
EditorData.NodeContext: Quick and eager,  not really giving the player chance to respond

Text.Value: Got a minute to tell me about your experience at the gate today?
Sorry. Can't talk. I'm on a deadline.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Lens has a pen and paper in hand, as if she's stood making notes/obsevations, and has stopped to talk to the player.

Text.Value: Mr Needle's gotten pally with that Lord Gortash, and suddenly can't sing his praises highly enough.
I'm going to ignore that comment, because clearly you aren't taking any of this seriously.

EditorData.NodeContext: Rising above it, a bit judgy

Text.Value: The Fist turned me away.
I'll try and get the truth across. Who knows, maybe a line or two will meet Mr Needle's approval. I won't be holding my breath.
And I'm not interested at all. Goodbye.
Of course we're off the record and this conversation never happened.

EditorData.NodeContext: backing out - they've strayed into very dangerous territory with this conversation

Text.Value: I'd love to speak with your editor. Where can I find him?
Now if you don't mind, I've got some edits to make.
Sounds like you're printing Gortash's propaganda.
Doesn't it just?

EditorData.NodeContext: with a sigh - can't believe it's come to this

Text.Value: My editor at the Baldur's Mouth Gazette sent me down to get a first-hand account of the chaos.
If you read the Baldur's Mouth Gazette, it's an opinion you'll never hear. Lord Gortash makes sure of that.
I'm not here to catch you out - I'm covering the closure of the gates for the Baldur's Mouth Gazette. My editor sent me.
There was a skirmish a few days back - a band of Absolutists came close to entering the city. People started panicking, so the gate got closed.
At the Gazette's print house. Though it's in the Lower City, so you'll need to get past the gates first.
Seems like everything we write needs Gortash's approval. I can't recognise my own work by the time they're done 'editing.'
Why's security so tight?
That the refugees here are desperate, hungry, scared people. They're no mob - they just want to be safe.
You, er, might want to speak to him about that. Set the record straight before the ink is dry, so to speak.
Oh, they know some of it. Most would rather bury their heads in the sand anyway. Saves them the bother of feeling responsible.
I've heard the rumours - Absolutists marching from Moonrise Towers, whole towns felled by strange curses. It's no wonder they ran.
Sounds about right. They're not letting anyone through without the proper permissions - Lord Gortash's orders.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Lens makes a quick note on her paper as she speaks

Text.Value: We are, and I am. It's my editor who seems to have forgotten.
Aha. I see you don't trust journalists. Can't say I blame you.
It was very good. The Fist were most accommodating.
And what do you think is the truth?
No comment.
That's appalling. So people in the city have no idea what's going on?
Have you considered that perhaps you're just not a very good writer?
I thought journalists were supposed to be impartial?
I'm Lens, roving reporter for the Baldur's Mouth Gazette. My editor's sent me to cover the drama out here at the gate.
Slow down a second. Who are you?
My editor Mr Needle was a brilliant journalist, but recently... well, now he's got friends in high places, he seems more interested in keeping them happy.

Synopsis:
At the end of the queue leading to the South span’s checkpoint is a young journalist taking note and quotes from the poor souls trying to get into Baldur’s Gate.

This is her normal state.
